--- title: Bar Charts and Histograms date: today date-format: long footer: "[DataViz 6502 Website](https://dataviz-esia.training)" logo: images/dataviz-logo.png format: revealjs: theme: [simple, custom.scss] transition: fade slide-number: true multiplex: true chalkboard: true execute: echo: false message: false warning: false freeze: auto --- ## The Grammar of Graphics - Data viz has a language with its own grammar - Basic components include: - Data we are trying to visualize - Aesthetics (dimensions) - Geom (e.g. bar, line, scatter plot) - Color scales - Themes - Annotations ## Let's start with the first two, the data and the aesthetic.
::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code code-line-numbers="6"} library(readr) library(ggplot2) dem_summary <- read_csv("data/dem_summary.csv") ggplot(dem_summary, aes(x = region, y = polyarchy)) ``` ::: ## Gives us the axes without any visualization.
::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](day-2.1_files/figure-revealjs/barchart1.1-1.png){width=960} ::: ::: ## Now let's add a geom. In this case we want a bar chart so we *add* `geom_col()`
::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot(dem_summary, aes(x = region, y = polyarchy)) + geom_col() ``` ::: ## OK but that gets the idea across but looks a little depressing so... ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](day-2.1_files/figure-revealjs/barchart2.1-1.png){width=960} ::: ::: ## ...let's change the color of the bars by specifying `fill = "steelblue"`.
::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code code-line-numbers="2"} ggplot(dem_summary, aes(x = region, y = polyarchy)) + geom_col(fill = "steelblue") ``` ::: ## Note how color of original bars is simply overwritten. ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](day-2.1_files/figure-revealjs/barchart3.1-1.png){width=960} ::: ::: ## Now let's *add* some labels with the `labs()` function:
::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code code-line-numbers="3-8"} ggplot(dem_summary, aes(x = region, y = polyarchy)) + geom_col(fill = "steelblue") + labs( x = "Region", y = "Avg. Polyarchy Score", title = "Democracy by region, 1990 - present", caption = "Source: V-Dem Institute" ) ``` ::: ## And that gives us... ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](day-2.1_files/figure-revealjs/barchart4.1-1.png){width=960} ::: ::: ## Next, we reorder the bars with the `reorder()` function.
::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code code-line-numbers="1"} ggplot(dem_summary, aes(x = reorder(region, -polyarchy), y = polyarchy)) + geom_col(fill = "steelblue") + labs( x = "Region", y = "Avg. Polyarchy Score", title = "Democracy by region, 1990 - present", caption = "Source: V-Dem Institute" ) ``` ::: ## This way, we get a nice, visually appealing ordering of the bars according to levels of democracy... ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](day-2.1_files/figure-revealjs/barchart5.1-1.png){width=960} ::: ::: ## Jumping ahead a little, let's change the theme to `theme_minimal()`.
::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code code-line-numbers="8"} ggplot(dem_summary, aes(x = reorder(region, -polyarchy), y = polyarchy)) + geom_col(fill = "steelblue") + labs( x = "Region", y = "Avg. Polyarchy Score", title = "Democracy by region, 1990 - present", caption = "Source: V-Dem Institute" ) + theme_minimal() ``` ::: ## Gives us a clean, elegant look. ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](day-2.1_files/figure-revealjs/barchart6.1-1.png){width=960} ::: ::: ## Note that you can also save your plot as an object to modify later.
::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} dem_bar_chart <- ggplot(dem_summary, aes(x = reorder(region, -polyarchy), y = polyarchy)) + geom_col(fill = "steelblue") ``` ::: ## Which gives us... ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} dem_bar_chart ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](day-2.1_files/figure-revealjs/barchart7.1-1.png){width=960} ::: ::: ## Now let's add our labels.
::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} dem_bar_chart <- dem_bar_chart + labs( x = "Region", y = "Avg. Polyarchy Score", title = "Democracy by region, 1990 - present", caption = "Source: V-Dem Institute" ) ``` ::: ## So now we have... ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} dem_bar_chart ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](day-2.1_files/figure-revealjs/barchart8.1-1.png){width=960} ::: ::: ## Now let's add our theme.
::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} dem_bar_chart <- dem_bar_chart + theme_minimal() ``` ::: ## Voila! ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} dem_bar_chart ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](day-2.1_files/figure-revealjs/barchart9.1-1.png){width=960} ::: ::: ## Change the theme. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} dem_bar_chart + theme_bw() ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](day-2.1_files/figure-revealjs/barchart10-1.png){width=960} ::: ::: ## Your Turn! {.smaller}
*Use your own wrangled data or this code to get started:*
::: {.cell evakl='false'} ```{.r .cell-code} library(readr) library(ggplot2) dem_summary <- read_csv("https://raw.githubusercontent.com/eteitelbaum/dataviz-fall-2023/main/modules/data/dem_summary.csv") ``` ::: ## 1. `glimpse()` the data 2. Find a new variable to visualize 3. Make a bar chart with it 4. Change the [color](http://sape.inf.usi.ch/quick-reference/ggplot2/colour) of the bars 5. Order the bars 6. Add labels 7. Add a [theme](https://ggplot2.tidyverse.org/reference/ggtheme.html) 8. Try saving your plot as an object 9. Then change the labels and/or theme ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}
10:00
``` ::: ::: ## Now Try a Histogram
*Use this code or your own wrangled data to get started*
::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} dem_women <- read_csv("https://raw.githubusercontent.com/eteitelbaum/dataviz-fall-2023/main/modules/data/dem_women.csv") ``` ::: ## 1. Pick a variable that you want to explore the distribution of 2. Make a histogram a. Only specify `x = ` in `aes()` b. Specify geom as `geom_histogram` 3. Choose color for bars 4. Choose appropriate labels 5. Add a theme ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}
10:00
``` ::: :::

<script>
  // htmlwidgets need to know to resize themselves when slides are shown/hidden.
  // Fire the "slideenter" event (handled by htmlwidgets.js) when the current
  // slide changes (different for each slide format).
  (function () {
    // dispatch for htmlwidgets
    function fireSlideEnter() {
      const event = window.document.createEvent("Event");
      event.initEvent("slideenter", true, true);
      window.document.dispatchEvent(event);
    }

    function fireSlideChanged(previousSlide, currentSlide) {
      fireSlideEnter();

      // dispatch for shiny
      if (window.jQuery) {
        if (previousSlide) {
          window.jQuery(previousSlide).trigger("hidden");
        }
        if (currentSlide) {
          window.jQuery(currentSlide).trigger("shown");
        }
      }
    }

    // hookup for slidy
    if (window.w3c_slidy) {
      window.w3c_slidy.add_observer(function (slide_num) {
        // slide_num starts at position 1
        fireSlideChanged(null, w3c_slidy.slides[slide_num - 1]);
      });
    }

  })();
</script>
